responses.rationale: The segment describes a consequence of the situation (labelling change) rather than a capability or preparedness measure.
The segment describes a past rule and current requirement, not a capability or preparedness measure against the disease.
Describes a future possibility ('When the measures... are lifted, eggs will go back...') without active reassurance.
Describes a safeguard ('temporarily housed to protect their health and welfare') without active reassurance.
Describes a future possibility ('Once the risk levels have reduced... birds will be able to go outside again') without active reassurance.
Describes a development capability ('France has been trialling bird flu vaccines') without active reassurance.
The segment is too short and lacks context to describe a capability or preparedness measure.
The segment mentions developments and concerns, not specific capabilities or preparedness measures.
The segment describes events (outbreaks) rather than capabilities or preparedness measures.
The segment describes events/developments (infected cows, human case) rather than capabilities or preparedness measures.
Describes agency focus ('taking bird flu seriously') and existing knowledge ('virus has already been well studied') without active reassurance.
Explicitly states preparedness ('weâ€™ve been preparing for avian flu for 20 years') without active reassurance.
The segment describes the virus's nature/evolution, not capabilities or preparedness measures.
The segment describes the spread of the virus, not capabilities or preparedness measures.
The segment describes detection/presence of the virus, not capabilities or preparedness measures.

The segment describes a lack of resources/capability, not a statement of existing capability or preparedness.

The segment describes findings/impact, not capabilities or preparedness measures.
